div.l: Thei gete him not so lightly bi my crown
¶ This sely clerkes rennen vp ⁊and down
Wᵗith kepe kepe stand stand Iest the war the rere
Go whistell thou ⁊and I shall kepe hym here
But shortly till hit was verrey night
Thei couthe not wᵗith bothe hur might
Hur capull cacche he ran a wey so faste
Till in a dyche thei caught him at the laste
Wery ⁊and wete as bestes ben in reyne
Cometh sely Iohn ⁊and after him Aleyne
Alas ꝙquod Iohn that I was born
Now be we dryuen to hethen ⁊and to skorn
Oure corn is stolen men wol vs fals calle
Bothe oure wardeyne ⁊and oure felawes alle
And namely the myller weyle away
¶ Thus playneth Iohn as he goth bi the way
Toward the mylle ⁊and bayard in his honde
The myller syttyng bi the fuyr he fonde
For hit was night ⁊and further might thei nought
But for the loue of god thei him bi sought
Of herberewe ⁊and of ese for hur peny
The myller onswered a yeyne if ther be eny
Suche as hit is yet shull ye haue your͗e part
Myn hows is strayt but ye haue lered art
Ye can bi argument maken a place
A myle brod of twenty fot a space
Let se now if this place may suffyse
Or make hit more wᵗith speche as is youre gyse
¶ Now symond seyde this Iohn bi seynt Cuthbert
Ay be thou mery for this is feyre onswerd
I haue herd sey men shulde take of two thynges
Such as he fyndeth or such as he brynges
